questionListItems.title: Will there be sufficient time for my child to pray?

answer.body: Students can pray when course schedule permits. This is because OBS course involve expeditions that start from morning and lasts throughout the day. The expeditions are conducted in terrains such as coastal area in the sea and forested area. The key priority is for the instructor to be able to account for the safety and learning of the whole group.

questionListItems.title: What type of food will be given to my child during pre-dawn and break-fast meals?

answer.body:
Pre-dawn and break-fast meals will be arranged by OBS. Pre-dawn meals typically consist of rations that are easy to cook, like Meals-Ready-to-Eat (MREs), instant noodles, or ketupat rice. Students can decide the duration they require for the meal.


Break-fast meals will be hot meals cooked by each group and typically at the end of each day’s expedition. Muslim students will also be given dates and other rations like buns and biscuits to supplement their meals.


Dinner for each group will be timed together with break-fast so that the whole group will be able to eat together. However, if dinner is not ready by the break-fast time e.g. due to bad weather, the instructors will ensure the Muslim students get to break-fast on time with their dates, buns and biscuits first, while waiting for dinner to be ready.

questionListItems.title: How will my child be woken up for his/her pre-dawn meal?

answer.body: All students are responsible for waking up on time during the course. Many do so with the help of other peers. As mobile phones are not allowed to be used during the course, your child may bring along and use an alarm clock or a watch with an alarm function.

questionListItems.title: Will activities be carried out as per normal during Ramadan and will my (fasting) child be required to participate in all activities?

answer.body: Yes. All activities will be carried out as per normal and your child will be participating in all the activities with the rest of their group members. Your child can alert the instructors if they have any concerns on the activities. Instructors will be aware of students who are fasting and will check-in with them regularly. As part of the instructors’ due care, the instructors will instruct the student to break their fast should the fasting regime affect their health or safety during the course.

questionListItems.title: If a Muslim student chooses to break fast in the midst of an activity, is that possible? Will there be meal or snack provided?

answer.body: Rations are given to the students and they will carry it (and their water bottles) with them so they can choose to break their fast when necessary. Students will also be briefed to alert the instructors, who will be able to advise and assist them.

questionListItems.title: Will Courses be scheduled during the fasting month? What steps are taken to ensure students’ well-being during the fasting month?

answer.body:
MOE works with OBS to conduct the MOE-OBS Challenge Programme up to 34 weeks in a year to enable more students to take part in the programme. The course may take place during the fasting month. While the course is physically demanding, additional precautions will be taken to ensure the students’ well-being, as with any other physical activities organised by schools during fasting month, e.g., PE lessons, CCAs. 

OBS has a set of guidelines for managing students who are fasting. Examples of these guidelines include conducting pre-activity checks, daily monitoring and briefing by a Muslim staff at the start of the course. This briefing will be further reinforced by the watch Instructors at appropriate times.

Students will be informed that the course will be physically demanding and challenging and that they will experience fatigue and thirst.  They will not be discouraged from fasting but will be reminded that if they do not feel well, they will be asked to break fast immediately to prevent endangering themselves. Pre-activity briefings will also cover information on the activity intensity such as the expedition distance, duration and environmental challenges.

The instructors will closely monitor students who are fasting and check on their condition regularly. Instructors will ensure that the students are given ample rations and water at all times. They will also remind the students on the timings for pre-dawn meals and break-fast meals. As part of the instructors’ due care, student will be instructed to break their fast should the fasting regime affect their safety during the course.

Safety rules, such as staying together with the group during activity time must be adhered to. As a mark of respect for those who are fasting, Instructors may allow them to sit away from the group during meal times in the day.

If students face any discomfort during the course, they can alert their instructor or any OBS staff.  Students will be referred to the OBS Medical Centre (where necessary) for assessment and monitoring.

questionListItems.title: My child would like to purchase OBS souvenirs after the Course. How much money should I advise them to bring?

answer.body: The OBS souvenir is now online. Your child can buy OBS branded souvenirs online at www.go.gov.sg/obsshop

questionListItems.title: Can the students join OBS alumni after the course?

answer.body:
OBS welcomes all participants to join our alumni to value-add to their Outward Bound experience! The Alumni aims to provide a platform exclusively for OBS Alumni to further develop themselves and build a close-knitted community of like-minded individuals, who have been inspired by their OBS experience to make a difference to the people and the environment. These can be achieved through the variety of opportunities to Serve, Grow and Inspire.

You may join as an alumni by completing the following form @ https://form.gov.sg/5d98a6cd7f5cfb0013139f2b

questionListItems.title: Will my child’s LEAPS 2.0 points be affected if they did not attend OBS or has to be out of course mid-way due to medical reasons?

answer.body: Please refer to the school for LEAPS 2.0 queries.

questionListItems.title: Do parents have to pay any fees for the OBS course?

answer.body: Parents do not need to pay a fee for the OBS course. With effect from 2021, the MOE-OBS Challenge Programme will be fully funded by MOE.

questionListItems.title: Must schools pay for students who require tetanus vaccination?

answer.body: Students who require the tetanus vaccination should pay for the additional cost incurred for the vaccination.

questionListItems.title: How can the safety of my child be ensured during the OBS Course, with a big group of students coming together?

answer.body:
Students undergo the course in a group of maximum 14 students per instructor, to facilitate safety supervision, healthy interaction, adequate peer support and opportunities to practice leadership roles.

 

During activities, the students are supervised by qualified OBS Instructors who are trained in Wilderness Advanced First Aid and have undergone a rigorous 6 to 8 months of training, technical skills assessments, and certifications.  

In addition, OBS has a robust safety monitoring system and evacuation plans for emergencies.

questionListItems.title: Can a child who wears hearing aids participate in water-based activities at OBS without their hearing aids, as the hearing aids are not waterproof?

answer.body:
If the student can hear without the hearing aid, he/she can participate in the water activities. However, if the student is unable to hear without the hearing aid, he/she will need to sit out of the water activities for their own safety.


Additionally, if the hearing aids require charging, parents should ensure that the student has sufficient external charging (e.g. power bank) for the hearing aids for the full duration of the course.


It is important for parents to declare all medical conditions, including the use of hearing aids, in the Course Registration Form. This will ensure that OBS provides the necessary support and resources for students to participate in the MOE-OBS Challenge Programme safely. The safety of the student is of utmost importance, and the student may participate only if it is assessed to be safe to do so. Any undeclared medical condition may impact the student’s OBS participation.

questionListItems.title: What are the typical injuries/illnesses treated by instructors and by the medical staff?

answer.body: OBS commonly treats minor injuries and illness such as fever, headache, mild allergy reaction, sprains/strains, small cuts and abrasions.

questionListItems.title: What happens if a student is not a strong swimmer or unable to swim? Will they be required to participate in water activities at OBS?

answer.body:
Students will not be forced to participate in any activities. Generally, instructors will adopt a progressive approach. Instructors will first guide students in a water confidence test conducted at shallow waters before moving on to deeper waters.

In addition, personal floatation devices (PFDs) will be provided for all participants.
